name.text: Relationship between the side lengths and areas of similar regular hexagons

questiontext.text:
The corresponding sides of two similar regular hexagons are \( {@s1@} \) and \( {@s2@} \) respectively.

(a) Find the ratio of their areas.
[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

(b). If the area of the smaller hexagon is \( {@A_small@} \), calculate the area of the larger hexagon.
Note: Write your answer correct to 2 decimal places [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

.

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

Determine the linear scale factor

The side lengths of the similar regular hexagons are:

Small hexagon: \( {@s1@} \)

Large hexagon: \( {@s2@} \)

The linear scale factor from the smaller to the larger hexagon is

\(k = \frac{@s2@}{@s1@}.\)

Ratio of their areas

For any pair of similar shapes, the ratio of their areas is the square of the ratio of their corresponding side lengths. Thus,

\(\text{Area ratio} = k^2 = \left(\frac{@s2@}{@s1@}\right)^2 = {@ratio_area@}. \)

Area of the larger hexagon

We are told that the area of the smaller hexagon = {@A_small@}.

To find the area of the larger hexagon, multiply by the area ratio:

\(A_{\text{large}}= A_{\text{small}} \cdot k^2= {@A_small@} \cdot {@ratio_area@} = {@A_large@}. \)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

feedbackvariables.text: correst_ans : if (ans1 = ta or ans1 = ta1) then 1 else 0; mistake_1 : if (ans1 = ta3 or ans1 = ta4) then 1 else 0;

node.description: Giving the ratio of sides instead of areas

truefeedback.text: It looks like you may have given the ratio of the corresponding side lengths instead of the ratio of the areas. Remember, for similar shapes, areas do not scale in the same way as lengths. To find the ratio of the areas, you need to square the ratio of the corresponding sides.

node.description: Using the linear scale factor instead of the area scale factor

truefeedback.text: It looks like you may have used the scale factor for lengths to calculate the area. Remember, areas of similar shapes scale with the square of the linear scale factor. Make sure you square the ratio of the corresponding sides before multiplying by the given area.

It looks like you may have used the scale factor in the wrong direction. Since you are finding the area of the larger hexagon, the scale factor should increase the area from the smaller one. Make sure the ratio you use reflects this enlargement.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
Giving the ratio of sides instead of areas
